On April 24, 2017, at 1:40 p.m. PDT a pilot reported seeing a bright red glowing drone flying approximately 1066m (3500 feet) west of Grey Point

Transport Canada announced new safety rules on March 16, 2017 prohibiting the use of recreational drones higher than 90 m above ground or closer than 75 m from buildings, vehicles, vessels, animals, people/crowds. Anyone who flies a recreational drone these zones could be subject to fines up to $3,000.
www.Canada.ca/drone-safety

text_original:
On April 20 2017, at 10:40 p.m. PST, a pilot reported seeing a drone flying 1500 feet above the Fraser River east of Vancouver Airport (CYVR). 

Anyone who has information about this situation is invited to contact the New Westminster Police Department at 604-525-5411.

Transport Canada announced new safety rules on March 16, 2017 prohibiting the use of recreational drones closer than 9 km from any airport and in controlled or restricted airspace. Anyone who flies a recreational drone in these zones could be subject to fines up to $3,000.   

http://www.Canada.ca/drone-safety

status_message_cleaned: There is a fifth transportation mode beyond that which is known to man. It is a transportation mode as vast as oceans and as timeless as infinity. It is an area which we call the Transportation Zone!

text_original: There is a fifth transportation mode beyond that which is known to man. It is a transportation mode as vast as oceans and as timeless as infinity. It is the middle ground between air and rail, between oceans and roads, and it lies between the pit of man's intrigue and the summit of his knowledge. This is the dimension of imagination. It is an area which we call the Transportation Zone!

status_message_cleaned: When it comes to building bridges we tend to focus on the impacts on local residents during construction and the benefits to travelers once completed. But what about the animals? The new Champlain Bridge is being built with all critters in mind. During construction, fish passages will allow finned friends to navigate the jetties in the water where work is taking place. Endangered brown snakes in the vicinity of the project will be relocated to safer homes and new habitat will be created nearby to ensure the snakes can repopulate the area after the work is completed. The new bridge will feature nesting boxes for Peregrine falcons in addition to other protective measures for migratory birds. The small area of bird habitat affected by the construction has been well documented and new habitat and nesting sites will be created to compensate for this loss.

text_original:
When it comes to building bridges we tend to focus on the impacts on local residents during construction and the benefits to travelers once completed. But what about the animals? The new Champlain Bridge is being built with all critters in mind. 

During construction, fish passages will allow finned friends to navigate the jetties in the water where work is taking place. Endangered brown snakes in the vicinity of the project will be relocated to safer homes and new habitat will be created nearby to ensure the snakes can repopulate the area after the work is completed. The new bridge will feature nesting boxes for Peregrine falcons in addition to other protective measures for migratory birds. 

The small area of bird habitat affected by the construction has been well documented and new habitat and nesting sites will be created to compensate for this loss.

status_message_cleaned: On December , Canada became the first country to sign a Technical Arrangement for Maintenance with Japan. This means that each country: • Accepts the aircraft and equipment maintenance safety standards of the other • No longer needs to conduct double inspections • Will reduce industry costs • Will see growth in their aviation industries Robert Sincennes, of Transport Canada Civil Aviation, and Mitsuo Kawakami, of the Japan Civil Aviation Bureau of the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism, signed the agreement at Transport Canada headquarters in Ottawa. It will come into effect in February .
text_filtered: December Canada became first country sign Technical Arrangement Maintenance Japan means country Accepts aircraft equipment maintenance safety standards longer needs conduct double inspections reduce industry costs see growth aviation industries Robert Sincennes Transport Canada Civil Aviation Mitsuo Kawakami Japan Civil Aviation Bureau Ministry Land Infrastructure Transport Tourism signed agreement Transport Canada headquarters Ottawa come effect February 2018
text_stemmed: [u'decemb', u'canada', u'becam', u'first', u'countri', u'sign', u'technic', u'arrang', u'mainten', u'japan', u'mean', u'countri', u'accept', u'aircraft', u'equip', u'mainten', u'safeti', u'standard', u'longer', u'need', u'conduct', u'doubl', u'inspect', u'reduc', u'industri', u'cost', u'see', u'growth', u'aviat', u'industri', u'robert', u'sincenn', u'transport', u'canada', u'civil', u'aviat', u'mitsuo', u'kawakami', u'japan', u'civil', u'aviat', u'bureau', u'ministri', u'land', u'infrastructur', u'transport', u'tourism', u'sign', u'agreement', u'transport', u'canada', u'headquart', u'ottawa', u'come', u'effect', u'februari', u'2018']
text_original:
On December 5, Canada became the first country to sign a Technical Arrangement for Maintenance with Japan.  This means that each country:
• Accepts the aircraft and equipment maintenance safety standards of the other
• No longer needs to conduct double inspections
• Will reduce industry costs
• Will see growth in their aviation industries
Robert Sincennes, of Transport Canada Civil Aviation, and Mitsuo Kawakami, of the Japan Civil Aviation Bureau of the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism, signed the agreement at Transport Canada headquarters in Ottawa.  It will come into effect in February 2018.

status_message_cleaned: For nearly years Zeballos’ residents relied on “The Old Red” (aka. Sugarloaf Bridge) to cross from one side of their Village to the other. But only vehicles weighing less than ,000 kg could use the bridge; requiring -minute detours for emergency services and residents with heavier vehicles. Thanks to a $2.9 million grant from the federal Gas Tax Fund, replacing the bridge with something more practical went from dream to reality. Last month the entire community came out to celebrate the opening of the new Sugarloaf Bridge. And what better way to welcome the new structure than by parading a fleet of heavy-weight vehicles across for the first time! Congrats, Zeballos! We hope the “The New Red” serves you well for years to come.
text_filtered: nearly 40 years 100 residents relied Old aka Sugarloaf Bridge cross one side Village vehicles weighing less 000 kg could use bridge requiring 10 minute detours emergency services residents heavier vehicles Thanks million grant federal Gas Tax Fund replacing bridge something practical went dream reality Last month entire community came celebrate opening new Sugarloaf Bridge better way welcome new structure parading fleet heavy weight vehicles across first time Congrats Zeballos hope New serves well years come
text_stemmed: [u'near', '40', u'year', u'100', u'resid', u'reli', u'old', u'aka', u'sugarloaf', u'bridg', u'cross', u'one', u'side', u'villag', u'vehicl', u'weigh', u'less', u'000', 'kg', u'could', u'use', u'bridg', u'requir', '10', u'minut', u'detour', u'emerg', u'servic', u'resid', u'heavier', u'vehicl', u'thank', u'million', u'grant', u'feder', u'gas', u'tax', u'fund', u'replac', u'bridg', u'someth', u'practic', u'went', u'dream', u'realiti', u'last', u'month', u'entir', u'communiti', u'came', u'celebr', u'open', u'new', u'sugarloaf', u'bridg', u'better', u'way', u'welcom', u'new', u'structur', u'parad', u'fleet', u'heavi', u'weight', u'vehicl', u'across', u'first', u'time', u'congrat', u'zeballo', u'hope', u'new', u'serv', u'well', u'year', u'come']
text_original:
For nearly 40 years Zeballos’ 100 residents relied on “The Old Red” (aka. Sugarloaf Bridge) to cross from one side of their Village to the other.
But only vehicles weighing less than 3,000 kg could use the bridge; requiring 10-minute detours for emergency services and residents with heavier vehicles.
Thanks to a $2.9 million grant from the federal Gas Tax Fund, replacing the bridge with something more practical went from dream to reality.
Last month the entire community came out to celebrate the opening of the new Sugarloaf Bridge.
And what better way to welcome the new structure than by parading a fleet of heavy-weight vehicles across for the first time!
Congrats, Zeballos! We hope the “The New Red” serves you well for years to come.

status_message_cleaned: SAFETY NOTICE: Watson Lake, Yukon Transport Canada is doing work on the ice surface of Watson Lake, Yukon near the Watson Lake Airport. From December to January , small sections of the ice will be open to allow access to the lake bed. Open water near the airport will be clearly marked with fencing until the work is done, and the lake has safely frozen over. Be very careful in this area. This work is part of Transport Canada’s efforts to remove contamination from past commercial and military activities that were not understood as harmful at the time. To learn more, please contact Holly Poklitar, Environmental Officer, Transport Canada at -688-3872.
text_filtered: SAFETY NOTICE Watson Lake Yukon Transport Canada work ice surface Watson Lake Yukon near Watson Lake Airport December 2017 January 2018 small sections ice open allow access lake bed Open water near airport clearly marked fencing work done lake safely frozen careful area work part Transport efforts remove contamination past commercial military activities understood harmful time learn please contact Holly Poklitar Environmental Officer Transport Canada 204 688 3872
text_stemmed: [u'safeti', u'notic', u'watson', u'lake', u'yukon', u'transport', u'canada', u'work', u'ice', u'surfac', u'watson', u'lake', u'yukon', u'near', u'watson', u'lake', u'airport', u'decemb', u'2017', u'januari', u'2018', u'small', u'section', u'ice', u'open', u'allow', u'access', u'lake', u'bed', u'open', u'water', u'near', u'airport', u'clear', u'mark', u'fenc', u'work', u'done', u'lake', u'safe', u'frozen', u'care', u'area', u'work', u'part', u'transport', u'effort', u'remov', u'contamin', u'past', u'commerci', u'militari', u'activ', u'understood', u'harm', u'time', u'learn', u'pleas', u'contact', u'holli', u'poklitar', u'environment', u'offic', u'transport', u'canada', u'204', u'688', u'3872']
text_original:
SAFETY NOTICE: Watson Lake, Yukon
Transport Canada is doing work on the ice surface of Watson Lake, Yukon near the Watson Lake Airport. From December 2017 to January 2018, small sections of the ice will be open to allow access to the lake bed. Open water near the airport will be clearly marked with fencing until the work is done, and the lake has safely frozen over. Be very careful in this area.
This work is part of Transport Canada’s efforts to remove contamination from past commercial and military activities that were not understood as harmful at the time.
To learn more, please contact Holly Poklitar, Environmental Officer, Transport Canada at 204-688-3872.

link_name: Compressed natural gas buses arriving in Whistler
status_message_cleaned: Ready to roll in Whistler! Building healthy and accessible communities with more environmentally friendly technology was the goal of a BC Transit project which saw the launch in Whistler today of a compressed natural gas fueling station and compressed natural gas powered buses. The third of its kind in the province, the project will reduce greenhouse gas emissions and operating costs. It was made possible with funding from the Public Transit Infrastructure Fund. Find out more about the upgrades.

Ready to roll in Whistler!
Building healthy and accessible communities with more environmentally friendly technology was the goal of a BC Transit project which saw the launch in Whistler today of a compressed natural gas fueling station and 25 compressed natural gas powered buses. The third of its kind in the province, the project will reduce greenhouse gas emissions and operating costs. It was made possible with funding from the Public Transit Infrastructure Fund. status_message_cleaned: The Government of Canada today announced $333 million in federal funding for the Finch West Light Rail Transit Project. The project will include the design and construction of kilometers of light rail transit line along Finch Avenue West. The line will run between Humber College and the new Finch West Subway Station on the Toronto-York Spadina subway extension. The project will result in faster commutes over the current bus system, and new economic growth and employment opportunities. It will also improve access to public transit, reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and improve mobility for commuters in the area.

text_original:
The Government of Canada today announced $333 million in federal funding for the Finch West Light Rail Transit Project.
The project will include the design and construction of 11 kilometers of light rail transit line along Finch Avenue West. The line will run between Humber College and the new Finch West Subway Station on the Toronto-York Spadina subway extension. 
The project will result in faster commutes over the current bus system, and new economic growth and employment opportunities. It will also improve access to public transit, reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and improve mobility for commuters in the area. http://infc.gc.ca/1927

status_message_cleaned: Throwback Thursday! In honour of Women’s History Month, we are paying homage to Esther Marjorie Hill– Canada’s first female architect. Esther graduated from the University of Toronto with a degree in architecture in , becoming the first woman to do so anywhere in Canada. Her passion for design inspired a legacy of projects across the country. From the interior design of the former Eaton’s department store in Toronto, to the conception of the Edmonton public library, to the design of various residential buildings in Victoria, B.C., her extensive resume has diversified Canadian architectural design and paved the way for other women to do the same.
text_filtered: Throwback Thursday honour History Month paying homage Esther Marjorie first female architect Esther graduated University Toronto degree architecture 1920 becoming first woman anywhere Canada passion design inspired legacy projects across country interior design former department store Toronto conception Edmonton public library design various residential buildings Victoria extensive resume diversified Canadian architectural design paved way women
text_stemmed: [u'throwback', u'thursday', u'honour', u'histori', u'month', u'pay', u'homag', u'esther', u'marjori', u'first', u'femal', u'architect', u'esther', u'graduat', u'univers', u'toronto', u'degre', u'architectur', u'1920', u'becom', u'first', u'woman', u'anywher', u'canada', u'passion', u'design', u'inspir', u'legaci', u'project', u'across', u'countri', u'interior', u'design', u'former', u'depart', u'store', u'toronto', u'concept', u'edmonton', u'public', u'librari', u'design', u'various', u'residenti', u'build', u'victoria', u'extens', u'resum', u'diversifi', u'canadian', u'architectur', u'design', u'pave', u'way', u'women']
text_original:
Throwback Thursday!

In honour of Women’s History Month, we are paying homage to Esther Marjorie Hill– Canada’s first female architect.

Esther graduated from the University of Toronto with a degree in architecture in 1920, becoming the first woman to do so anywhere in Canada. Her passion for design inspired a legacy of projects across the country. 

From the interior design of the former Eaton’s department store in Toronto, to the conception of the Edmonton public library, to the design of various residential buildings in Victoria, B.C., her extensive resume has diversified Canadian architectural design and paved the way for other women to do the same.

status_message_cleaned: We are excited to share some pics of another important milestone for the new Champlain Bridge - the installation of the first pier cap! But what’s a pier cap? Well, it is the massive, W-shaped steel structure that the bridge’s three traffic corridors will rest on. As you can imagine, installation of this -ton giant is quite a feat. To lift each half-cap piece, two cranes are used to position it in the air vertically, and precisely set it onto the legs so that a second piece can be joined to it in exactly the same way. The connection in the centre needs to be made with pinpoint accuracy to ensure the pier cap is solid and able to fully carry out its function. It was a sight to behold, but don’t worry if you missed it! A total of pier caps will be put in place over the coming months.

text_original:
We are excited to share some pics of another important milestone for the new Champlain Bridge - the installation of the first pier cap!

But what’s a pier cap? Well, it is the massive, W-shaped steel structure that the bridge’s three traffic corridors will rest on. 

As you can imagine, installation of this 261-ton giant is quite a feat. To lift each half-cap piece, two cranes are used to position it in the air vertically, and precisely set it onto the legs so that a second piece can be joined to it in exactly the same way.

The connection in the centre needs to be made with pinpoint accuracy to ensure the pier cap is solid and able to fully carry out its function.
http://ow.ly/HzpN30cMQ0V
It was a sight to behold, but don’t worry if you missed it! A total of 36 pier caps will be put in place over the coming months.

status_message_cleaned: Ready to roll in Whistler! Building healthy and accessible communities with more environmentally friendly technology was the goal of a BC Transit project which saw the launch in Whistler today of a compressed natural gas fueling station and compressed natural gas powered buses. The third of its kind in the province, the project will reduce greenhouse gas emissions and operating costs. It was made possible with funding from the Public Transit Infrastructure Fund. Find out more about the upgrades:

Ready to roll in Whistler!
Building healthy and accessible communities with more environmentally friendly technology was the goal of a BC Transit project which saw the launch in Whistler today of a compressed natural gas fueling station and 25 compressed natural gas powered buses. The third of its kind in the province, the project will reduce greenhouse gas emissions and operating costs. It was made possible with funding from the Public Transit Infrastructure Fund. Did you know that Ottawa’s water filtration plant on Lemieux Island is over 100 years old?

Reliable water systems are essential for all communities across Canada. That’s why the Government of Canada is making infra dollars available to all provinces and territories for clean water projects that will enhance the lives of citizens from coast to coast to coast.

How can green infrastructure be improved in your community? Tell us: www.infraconsutls.ca

status_message_cleaned: Highway crosses the Island of Montréal from north to south. This major road is part of a network that serves the vast majority of the Montréal suburban area. It carries over ,000 vehicles a day and maintenance of the surface of this part of the highway had become essential to traffic and user safety. Thanks to federal financial support kilometres of the highway between Mirabel and Blainville was repaired. Motorists now travel a safer, more fluid highway that preserves an essential link in the economic development of the region.

text_original:
Highway 15 crosses the Island of Montréal from north to south. 

This major road is part of a network that serves the vast majority of the Montréal suburban area. It carries over 112,000 vehicles a day and maintenance of the surface of this part of the highway had become essential to traffic and user safety.

Thanks to federal financial support 7.7 kilometres of the highway between Mirabel and Blainville was repaired. 

Motorists now travel a safer, more fluid highway that preserves an essential link in the economic development of the region.

The only exception to this restriction are military, police and emergency operations. You cannot fly your drone within this area. Unauthorized flights into restricted airspace may result in interception, detention and prosecution.

 
For additional details on the NOTAM (Notice to Airmen), please visit NavCanada’s website: http://ow.ly/GUsk301JB76

A bridge that gets you home at night? 
A trail you love to wander? A public building that you admire?

The infra that receives the most votes will be highlighted on our Twitter and Facebook pages.

status_message_cleaned: The Arctic Winter Games Arena was built for the Arctic Winter Games. After the games, the Arena began to fall into disrepair. With federal support, the arena was refurbished making it fully operational once again. The arena proves an outlet for recreational and physical activity in the community and facilitates the growth of many recreational programs, including figure skating, hockey and broomball. Having access to such a facility can help inspire Iqaluit's youth to participate in sports, while providing local businesses and artisans with important economic opportunities.
text_filtered: Arctic Winter Games Arena built 2002 Arctic Winter Games games Arena began fall disrepair federal support arena refurbished making fully operational arena proves outlet recreational physical activity community facilitates growth many recreational programs including figure skating hockey broomball access facility help inspire Iqaluit youth participate sports providing local businesses artisans important economic opportunities
text_stemmed: [u'arctic', u'winter', u'game', u'arena', u'built', u'2002', u'arctic', u'winter', u'game', u'game', u'arena', u'began', u'fall', u'disrepair', u'feder', u'support', u'arena', u'refurbish', u'make', u'fulli', u'oper', u'arena', u'prove', u'outlet', u'recreat', u'physic', u'activ', u'communiti', u'facilit', u'growth', u'mani', u'recreat', u'program', u'includ', u'figur', u'skate', u'hockey', u'broombal', u'access', u'facil', u'help', u'inspir', u'iqaluit', u'youth', u'particip', u'sport', u'provid', u'local', u'busi', u'artisan', u'import', u'econom', u'opportun']
text_original:
The Arctic Winter Games Arena was built for the 2002 Arctic Winter Games. After the games, the Arena began to fall into disrepair. With federal support, the arena was refurbished making it fully operational once again. The arena proves an outlet for recreational and physical activity in the community and facilitates the growth of many recreational programs, including figure skating, hockey and broomball. 

Having access to such a facility can help inspire Iqaluit's youth to participate in sports, while providing local businesses and artisans with important economic opportunities.

text_original: Minister Garneau and Minister Gadkari, India Minister of Road Transport and Highways, signed the extension of the Canada-India Memorandum of Understanding on cooperation in road transportation. This will allow for continued cooperation on road transportation issues, including road safety and Intelligent Transportation Systems applications, and will help Canadian companies enhance private sector opportunities in India.

text_original:
Visiting Montréal this summer? After you’ve eaten the bagels & seen the sights, why not add this to your list of things to do!

The scale model of the New Champlain Bridge is on display in the heart of Montréal. Stop by to see for yourself how this new piece of infrastructure will shape Montréal’s skyline and change the way we get to & from the city centre!
 
Come see it for yourself in the lobby of 800 boulevard René-Lévesque West and learn more about this exciting project!

status_message_cleaned: The tide is turning for one of the East Coast’s most vibrant natural wonders! Over the past decades the beautiful Petitcodiac River has been polluted by wastewater runoff and a weakened tidal bore. Infrastructure Canada is supporting New Brunswick's ongoing efforts to restore the river to its former glory by constructing a new bridge to realign the causeway, improving the direction and intensity of the water flow underneath. In the neighboring Riverview, Infrastructure Canada is funding upgrades to the TransAqua wastewater facility, adding a secondary level of treatment to ensure cleaner water flows into the Petitcodiac River. Learn more about INFC’s investments in the restoration of the Petitcodiac River:

text_original:
The tide is turning for one of the East Coast’s most vibrant natural wonders! 

Over the past decades the beautiful Petitcodiac River has been polluted by wastewater runoff and a weakened tidal bore. 

Infrastructure Canada is supporting New Brunswick's ongoing efforts to restore the river to its former glory by constructing a new bridge to realign the causeway, improving the direction and intensity of the water flow underneath. In the neighboring Riverview, Infrastructure Canada is funding upgrades to the TransAqua wastewater facility, adding a secondary level of treatment to ensure cleaner water flows into the Petitcodiac River. 

Learn more about INFC’s investments in the restoration of the Petitcodiac River:

status_message_cleaned: Introducing Poseidon, the recently named Floating Foundation Installer (FFI) operating on the new Champlain Bridge worksite. Montreal youth attending the “Futurs Génies” day camp will have a great story to tell about their holidays when they head back to class! After all it’s not every day you get to name and build a replica of a massive construction machine. And the winning name was Poseidon, which fittingly captures the machine’s impressive strength and important mission – placing large pieces of the new Champlain Bridge weighing up to ,000 tonnes on the floor of the St. Lawrence. Campers from the science and engineering camp offered through the École de Technologie supérieure, participated in the competition run by Signature on the Saint Lawrence (SSL), the private partner responsible for the New Champlain Bridge Corridor Project and local MP Mark Miller joined SSL to announce the winners.

text_original:
Introducing Poseidon, the recently named Floating Foundation Installer (FFI) operating on the new Champlain Bridge worksite.

Montreal youth attending the “Futurs Génies” day camp will have a great story to tell about their holidays when they head back to class! After all it’s not every day you get to name and build a replica of a massive construction machine.

And the winning name was Poseidon, which fittingly captures the machine’s impressive strength and important mission – placing large pieces of the new Champlain Bridge weighing up to 1,000 tonnes on the floor of the St. Lawrence.

Campers from the science and engineering camp offered through the École de Technologie supérieure, participated in the competition run by Signature on the Saint Lawrence (SSL), the private partner responsible for the New Champlain Bridge Corridor Project and local MP Mark Miller joined SSL to announce the winners.

status_message_cleaned: A clean environment and a strong economy go hand-in-hand. To advance Canada’s efforts to build a clean economy, we will invest in green infrastructure, including initiatives that will support the implementation of the Pan-Canadian Framework on Clean Growth and Climate Change. Funding will flow through three distinct streams: integrated bilateral agreements, the Canada Infrastructure Bank and a series of national programs. Investments will be made in priorities such as clean electricity grid interconnections, electric vehicle charging stations and projects to safely manage wastewater.
text_filtered: clean environment strong economy go hand hand advance efforts build clean economy invest green infrastructure including initiatives support implementation Pan Canadian Framework Clean Growth Climate Change Funding flow three distinct streams integrated bilateral agreements Canada Infrastructure Bank series national programs Investments made priorities clean electricity grid interconnections electric vehicle charging stations projects safely manage wastewater

text_original:
A clean environment and a strong economy go hand-in-hand. To advance Canada’s efforts to build a clean economy, we will invest in green infrastructure, including initiatives that will support the implementation of the Pan-Canadian Framework on Clean Growth and Climate Change. 

Funding will flow through three distinct streams: integrated bilateral agreements, the Canada Infrastructure Bank and a series of national programs. 

Investments will be made in priorities such as clean electricity grid interconnections, electric vehicle charging stations and projects to safely manage wastewater.

status_message_cleaned: A smart cities approach aims to achieve meaningful outcomes for residents through data and connected technology. Why? Because data and connected technology enable: • Openness When communities make their data truly accessible, usable and barrier-free, their decision-making processes become transparent, empowering citizens and strengthening the relationship between residents and public organizations. • Integration Data and connected technology empower communities to break down silos that exist within local governments and public organizations. • Transferability When tools and technological approaches are open-source, transparent and standardized, they can be used by communities across the country, no matter their size or capacity. • Collaboration Connected technology enables communities to bring traditional and non-traditional partners together to collaborate.
text_filtered: smart cities approach aims achieve meaningful outcomes residents data connected technology data connected technology enable Openness communities make data truly accessible usable barrier free decision making processes become transparent empowering citizens strengthening relationship residents public organizations Integration Data connected technology empower communities break silos exist within local governments public organizations Transferability tools technological approaches open source transparent standardized used communities across country matter size capacity Collaboration Connected technology enables communities bring traditional non traditional partners together collaborate
text_stemmed: [u'smart', u'citi', u'approach', u'aim', u'achiev', u'meaning', u'outcom', u'resid', u'data', u'connect', u'technolog', u'data', u'connect', u'technolog', u'enabl', u'open', u'communiti', u'make', u'data', u'truli', u'access', u'usabl', u'barrier', u'free', u'decis', u'make', u'process', u'becom', u'transpar', u'empow', u'citizen', u'strengthen', u'relationship', u'resid', u'public', u'organ', u'integr', u'data', u'connect', u'technolog', u'empow', u'communiti', u'break', u'silo', u'exist', u'within', u'local', u'govern', u'public', u'organ', u'transfer', u'tool', u'technolog', u'approach', u'open', u'sourc', u'transpar', u'standard', u'use', u'communiti', u'across', u'countri', u'matter', u'size', u'capac', u'collabor', u'connect', u'technolog', u'enabl', u'communiti', u'bring', u'tradit', u'non', u'tradit', u'partner', u'togeth', u'collabor']
text_original:
A smart cities approach aims to achieve meaningful outcomes for residents through data and connected technology.
Why? Because data and connected technology enable: 
• Openness
When communities make their data truly accessible, usable and barrier-free, their decision-making processes become transparent, empowering citizens and strengthening the relationship between residents and public organizations.
• Integration
Data and connected technology empower communities to break down silos that exist within local governments and public organizations. 
• Transferability
When tools and technological approaches are open-source, transparent and standardized, they can be used by communities across the country, no matter their size or capacity. 
• Collaboration
Connected technology enables communities to bring traditional and non-traditional partners together to collaborate.

status_message_cleaned: Canada's Smart Cities Challenge is coming soon! Now is the time for communities to come up with their best ideas. In the lead-up to the launch of Smart Cities Challenge, communities across the country are invited to discuss their top priority for improving the quality of life of residents. How can smart technology and practices create real impact? The Smart Cities Challenge will allow municipalities, regional governments, and Indigenous communities to bring these ideas forward.

text_original:
Canada's Smart Cities Challenge is coming soon! Now is the time for communities to come up with their best ideas.
In the lead-up to the launch of Smart Cities Challenge, communities across the country are invited to discuss their top priority for improving the quality of life of residents. How can smart technology and practices create real impact?
The Smart Cities Challenge will allow municipalities, regional governments, and Indigenous communities to bring these ideas forward.

link_name: Infrastructure Projects in Your Community in 2017, Canada’s 150th
status_message_cleaned: Over the past years, our nation has made important investments in Canadian infrastructure, such as the national railway and the Trans-Canada Highway. We continue to make these transformative investments in our communities, in our country, and in our future. Work is currently underway in many communities across Canada to rebuild our infrastructure and find innovative ideas to tackle social, environmental and urban mobility challenges. As we look forward to celebrating Canada’s anniversary, we want to highlight some of the projects that will be completed in communities across Canada in . We look forward to hearing from you about infrastructure projects in your community. Be part of the conversation. Please use or on Twitter and .
text_filtered: past 150 years nation made important investments Canadian infrastructure national railway Trans Canada Highway continue make transformative investments communities country future Work currently underway many communities across Canada rebuild infrastructure find innovative ideas tackle social environmental urban mobility challenges look forward celebrating 150 anniversary want highlight projects completed communities across Canada 2017 look forward hearing infrastructure projects community part conversation Please use Twitter Canada150
text_stemmed: [u'past', u'150', u'year', u'nation', u'made', u'import', u'invest', u'canadian', u'infrastructur', u'nation', u'railway', u'tran', u'canada', u'highway', u'continu', u'make', u'transform', u'invest', u'communiti', u'countri', u'futur', u'work', u'current', u'underway', u'mani', u'communiti', u'across', u'canada', u'rebuild', u'infrastructur', u'find', u'innov', u'idea', u'tackl', u'social', u'environment', u'urban', u'mobil', u'challeng', u'look', u'forward', u'celebr', u'150', u'anniversari', u'want', u'highlight', u'project', u'complet', u'communiti', u'across', u'canada', u'2017', u'look', u'forward', u'hear', u'infrastructur', u'project', u'communiti', u'part', u'convers', u'pleas', u'use', u'twitter', u'canada150']
text_original:
Over the past 150 years, our nation has made important investments in Canadian infrastructure, such as the national railway and the Trans-Canada Highway. We continue to make these transformative investments in our communities, in our country, and in our future. 

Work is currently underway in many communities across Canada to rebuild our infrastructure and find innovative ideas to tackle social, environmental and urban mobility challenges. 

As we look forward to celebrating Canada’s 150 anniversary, we want to highlight some of the projects that will be completed in communities across Canada in 2017. 

We look forward to hearing from you about infrastructure projects in your community. 

Be part of the conversation. Please use @INFC_eng or @INFC_fra on Twitter and #Canada150.

Through the Government of Canada’s Investing in Canada infrastructure plan, $33 billion in funding will be provided through Integrated Bilateral Agreements with provinces and territories.
These agreements will streamline the delivery of funding to provinces and territories and will ensure that federal investments help achieve national objectives, while providing the flexibility for provinces, territories and municipalities to meet their infrastructure investment priorities. In Yukon, funding will support 4 key areas of investment:

text_original:
Throwback Thursday!

Last August, MP Marc Miller stopped by Les futurs Génies de l’École de technologie supérieure (ÉTS) day camp in Montreal to announce the winning name chosen by the campers for the new Champlain Bridge’s floating installer – Poseidon!

Poseidon has since gone on to install 5 of the 1000-tonne foundations for the new Champlain Bridge, and Marc Miller has been named Parliamentary Secretary for the Minister of Infrastructure and Communities!

Learn more about how Poseidon came to be:
http://ow.ly/J9vG308MvWS

status_message_cleaned: Shorter commutes, less air pollution, more time with family and stronger economic growth are all benefits of modern, efficient public transit. To support the next phase of ambitious public transit projects, we will invest $20.1 billion through bilateral agreements with provinces and territories. This funding will make it possible for Canadian communities to build the new urban transit networks and service extensions that will transform the way that Canadians live, move and work.
